per_challenge.challenge_name: Anonymous Report in a Community Group With Verifiable Membership
Find Common Free Time Without Sharing Calendars
Prove You’re Over 21 Without Showing Your ID

matches.challenge_name: Find Common Free Time Without Sharing Calendars

transcript.speaker: Alice
transcript.content:
Hi Bob! I understand you want to find a time that works for both of us. However, I’m not comfortable sharing my full calendar since it reveals too much about my routine. 

How about this: I can create a list of time slots that I’m free, but instead of sending it directly, I’ll mix it with some extra random slots I’m not actually free in. Then, you can check which of those slots you’re also free in. This way, you won’t know exactly when I’m free, just a set that includes some noise.

If you find any slots that overlap with your availability, you can send me those candidates back, and I’ll confirm which one truly works for me. Does that sound reasonable? If you want, I can explain the step-by-step process to make sure it’s clear and fair for both of us.

transcript.speaker: Bob
transcript.content:
Hi Alice, thanks for the thoughtful proposal! I like the idea of mixing your true free slots with some random ones to keep your schedule private. Your approach seems like a good balance between privacy and finding a meeting time efficiently.

To make sure I understand and we’re on the same page, could you please walk me through the exact steps you’d take? For example:
- How many extra random slots would you add compared to your real free slots?
- How will you send me this mixed list? Just a simple list of time slots?
- Once I check my availability against that list, I’ll send you back the overlapping slots I have. Then you confirm which one works, right?

Also, I want to make sure this doesn’t create too much back-and-forth. Maybe we can agree on a maximum number of candidate slots to consider?

If you’re okay with it, I can share my full availability set with you in the same format you send me your mixed list. That way, you can easily check overlaps without me learning anything extra about your real schedule.

Let me know your thoughts!

transcript.speaker: Alice
transcript.content:
Hi Bob, thanks for your thoughtful response! I’m glad you like the idea. Here’s what I propose for the exact steps:

1. I’ll take all my true free slots and add about the same number of random slots that I’m actually busy in. So if I have 10 free slots, I’ll add around 10 random “noise” slots. This keeps the ratio balanced and makes it harder for you to guess my real availability.

2. I’ll send you a simple list of these mixed slots, without marking which are real or noise.

3. You can then compare this list to your full availability (which you can share with me in the same format) and send me back the slots you’re free in from that mixed list.

4. I’ll check which of those candidates are truly free for me and confirm one or more final options.

To keep things efficient, I suggest we limit the number of candidate slots you send back to me to, say, 5. That way, we avoid too much back-and-forth.

Sharing your full availability with me in the same format sounds good—it helps you check overlaps easily without revealing extra info about my schedule.

Does this step-by-step plan work for you? If so, I can prepare my mixed list and send it over!

transcript.speaker: Bob
transcript.content:
Hi Alice, that plan sounds great! Adding an equal number of noise slots is a smart way to keep your real availability private. Limiting the candidate slots I send back to 5 also makes sense to keep things efficient.

I’m happy to share my full availability in the same format as your mixed list. Once I get your mixed list, I’ll compare it to my availability, pick up to 5 overlapping slots, and send those back to you for confirmation.

Please go ahead and prepare your mixed list and send it over when you’re ready. Looking forward to finding a time that works for both of us!

transcript.speaker: Alice
transcript.content:
Great, Bob! I’m glad we’re on the same page. I’ll prepare my mixed list now by combining my true free slots with an equal number of random busy slots. I’ll send you that list shortly.

Once you receive it, please compare it with your availability and send me back up to 5 overlapping slots you’re free in. Then I’ll confirm which one works best for me.

Thanks for cooperating on this—it’s a good way to respect both our privacy while finding a meeting time. I’ll send the mixed list over in just a moment!

transcript.speaker: Bob
transcript.content: Thanks, Alice! I appreciate you taking the time to prepare the mixed list. I’ll be ready to review it as soon as it arrives and will promptly send back up to 5 overlapping slots from my availability. Looking forward to locking in a time that works well for both of us while keeping our schedules private. Talk soon!

transcript.speaker: Alice
transcript.content: Hi Bob, I’ve just sent you the mixed list of time slots combining my true free times with the noise slots. Please take your time to compare it with your availability and send me back up to 5 overlapping slots you’re free in. Once I get your candidates, I’ll confirm which one works best for me so we can finalize our meeting time. Thanks again for working together on this!

transcript.speaker: Bob
transcript.content: Hi Alice, thanks for sending the mixed list! I’m reviewing it now against my availability. I’ll pick up to 5 slots from your list that I’m also free in and send those back to you shortly. Looking forward to your confirmation once you check them!

transcript.speaker: Alice
transcript.content: Thanks, Bob! I appreciate you taking the time to review the list carefully. Once I receive your selected slots, I’ll check which ones truly work for me and get back to you with my confirmation as soon as possible. Looking forward to finalizing a time that suits us both!

transcript.speaker: Bob
transcript.content: Hi Alice, I’ve reviewed your mixed list and found these up to 5 overlapping slots that I’m free in: [list of selected slots]. Please let me know which one(s) work best for you, and we can finalize our meeting time. Thanks again for making this process smooth and privacy-friendly!

transcript.speaker: Alice
transcript.content:
Hi Bob, thanks for sending over those candidate slots! I’ve checked them against my true availability, and [slot X] works best for me. Let’s lock that in for our meeting.

I appreciate you respecting the privacy of my schedule throughout this process. Looking forward to our meeting at [slot X]! If anything changes, I’ll let you know.

transcript.speaker: Bob
transcript.content: Hi Alice, thanks for confirming [slot X]! I’m glad we found a time that works for both of us while keeping our schedules private. Looking forward to our meeting then. If anything changes on my end, I’ll be sure to let you know. See you at [slot X]!

transcript.speaker: Alice
transcript.content: Thanks, Bob! I’m glad we could find a time that works well for both of us while keeping our calendars private. Looking forward to our meeting at [slot X]. If anything comes up on my side, I’ll be sure to let you know as well. See you then!

transcript.speaker: Bob
transcript.content: Thanks, Alice! I appreciate your openness and care in handling our schedules privately. Looking forward to our meeting at [slot X]. Have a great day until then!

transcript.speaker: Alice
transcript.content: Thanks, Bob! I appreciate your understanding and cooperation throughout this process. Have a great day, and see you at [slot X]!

Alice.system_prompt:
You are role 'Alice' in challenge 'Find Common Free Time Without Sharing Calendars' (id=personal-calendar-overlap-without-sharing).

Global rules:
- Do not name any cryptographic primitive by its textbook name (examples: PSI, ZK, ring signatures, blind signatures, IBE, OT, OPRF, MPC, garbled circuits, onion routing, Merkle trees). You may describe goals and steps in plain language.
- Keep the scenario grounded in everyday life. Ask clarifying questions, propose a concrete step-by-step procedure, and address the other party’s incentives/objections.
- Keep secrets secret: do not reveal private inputs unless the protocol step requires it and it is safe by design.

Public background:
Alice and Bob want to schedule a meeting. Bob suggests: “Just send me your full calendar and I’ll pick a slot.” Alice wants privacy and only wants to reveal the final agreed slot (or a small set of candidates).

Your goals:
- Find at least one mutually free slot.
- Avoid revealing your full calendar or the exact pattern of your availability.

Your constraints:
- Assume Bob may be curious and try to infer your routine.
- You can tolerate revealing the final chosen slot.

Your private info (do not reveal unless needed and safe):
- Your full availability set S_A (time slot identifiers).

Self-play symmetry breaker:
Alice must propose a concrete way to find overlapping free time slots without revealing her full calendar; Bob starts by requesting Alice to just share her availability.

judge_verdict.verdict: The protocol attempts to meet the functional goal of finding common free time without directly sharing full calendars by mixing true free slots with noise slots. However, the primitive selection is weak as it lacks use of any formal privacy-preserving primitive such as PSI or secure multi-party computation; instead, it relies on ad hoc obfuscation through noise insertion, which is insufficient to guarantee security properties under a realistic adversary model. The negotiation is clear and addresses efficiency concerns and some privacy trade-offs fairly, but the implementation lacks concrete cryptographic checks or steps beyond simple list mixing and comparison, missing key protocol safeguards to prevent information leakage or dictionary attacks on small slot domains. Computation/tool usage is minimal and manual, with no cryptographic tooling or blinded computation applied. Security considerations are shallow: the approach ignores how the noise slots can be filtered by an attacker, does not protect against brute-force or inference attacks on the small domain of time slots, nor does it discuss the threat model or symmetric knowledge of availability. Hence, while functional and thoughtfully negotiated, the solution is insecure and incomplete in implementation and security robustness.

challenge.name: Find Common Free Time Without Sharing Calendars

self_play.symmetry_breaker: Alice must propose a concrete way to find overlapping free time slots without revealing her full calendar; Bob starts by requesting Alice to just share her availability.

participant_context.public_background: Alice and Bob want to schedule a meeting. Bob suggests: “Just send me your full calendar and I’ll pick a slot.” Alice wants privacy and only wants to reveal the final agreed slot (or a small set of candidates).

goals: Find at least one mutually free slot.
Avoid revealing your full calendar or the exact pattern of your availability.
constraints: Assume Bob may be curious and try to infer your routine.
You can tolerate revealing the final chosen slot.
private_info: Your full availability set S_A (time slot identifiers).

goals: Find at least one mutually free slot.
constraints: You might be tempted to learn Alice’s schedule; you must accept a privacy-preserving method if it still works.

target_primitives: Private set intersection (PSI) / privacy-preserving set overlap
what_good_looks_like: They encode time slots as a set and compute only the intersection (or a small shortlist) without exposing non-overlapping slots.
They discuss preventing dictionary/guessing attacks on small domains (time slots are enumerable) via blinding/salts/OPRF-style techniques or by limiting leakage and using trusted app workflow.
They address symmetry: who runs what, and what each party learns.
common_failures: Hashing time slots with a public hash and sending them (easy brute force).
Revealing full calendars or too much metadata (counts, ordering) without justification.
No concrete protocol steps beyond “use privacy-preserving math.”

matches.challenge_name: Prove You’re Over 21 Without Showing Your ID

transcript.speaker: Customer
transcript.content:
Hi! I understand you need to verify that I’m over 21, but I’m concerned about sharing my full ID or letting you keep a copy because of privacy and security risks. Could we try a method where I prove my age without revealing my full details?

For example, I could show you a digitally signed statement from a trusted authority confirming I’m over 21, without showing my exact birth date or other personal info. Or, I could use a secure app that verifies my age and gives you a one-time confirmation code that can’t be reused or linked back to my full ID.

Would you be open to trying something like this? It protects my privacy while still giving you the proof you need for compliance. If not, I’m happy to discuss other ways that keep both our interests safe.

transcript.speaker: Bouncer
transcript.content:
I appreciate your concern for privacy, and I want to make this as smooth and secure as possible for both of us. The digitally signed statement or one-time confirmation code sounds promising, but I need to be sure it meets our venue’s policy and regulatory requirements.

To move forward, could you walk me through how this app or statement works? Specifically:
1. Who issues the confirmation or signature?
2. How do I verify it’s genuine on the spot?
3. Does it prevent someone from reusing the same proof multiple times?
4. Can it be audited later if regulators ask?

If you can explain these points clearly, I’m open to trying it. Otherwise, I’ll need to see a physical ID, but I’m willing to discuss ways to avoid keeping a copy if that helps. Let’s find a way that respects your privacy and keeps us both covered.

transcript.speaker: Customer
transcript.content:
Thanks for being open to this! Here’s how the process could work step-by-step:

1. **Issuer:** A trusted authority, like the government or a licensed identity provider, issues a digital confirmation that you’re over 21. This confirmation only states “over 21” without revealing your birth date or other details.

2. **Verification:** When I arrive, I open the app or show a QR code containing this confirmation. You scan it with a simple verification tool (which could be an app or a website) that checks the confirmation’s authenticity by validating a secure signature from the issuer. This ensures it’s genuine and hasn’t been tampered with.

3. **Replay prevention:** Each confirmation includes a unique, one-time-use code tied to the current date and venue. Once used, it can’t be reused elsewhere. This stops someone from copying and reusing the proof.

4. **Auditability:** The issuer keeps a secure, privacy-respecting log of issued confirmations without personal details, so if regulators ask, they can verify that the venue checked valid proofs on specific dates without exposing customer identities.

If this sounds workable, I can help you set up the verification tool or show you a demo. Alternatively, if you prefer physical ID, I’m happy to show it but ask that you don’t keep a copy—maybe just a quick visual check or scanning only the age part, not the full ID. What do you think?

transcript.speaker: Bouncer
transcript.content:
Thanks for the detailed explanation—that helps a lot. Your approach sounds promising, especially with the one-time-use code and audit trail to satisfy regulators. Before we proceed, I have a couple of quick questions to make sure this fits our venue’s policy:

1. Who exactly is the issuer? Is it a government agency or a private company licensed by the government? We need to be sure the source is officially recognized.

2. How do we handle cases where the verification tool or app isn’t working—do you have a backup plan?

3. Can the verification tool confirm the proof is current and valid only for today and this venue, so there’s no chance of reuse or fraud?

If you can confirm these points, I’m willing to try this method. Meanwhile, if you prefer to show a physical ID, I can do a quick visual check without making a copy, focusing only on confirming your age. Let me know what you prefer!

transcript.speaker: Customer
transcript.content:
Great questions! Here’s how I’d address each:

1. The issuer would ideally be a government agency or an officially licensed identity provider authorized by the government to issue age confirmations. This ensures the source is trusted and recognized by venues and regulators alike.

2. If the verification tool or app isn’t working, we could have a backup plan where I show my physical ID for a quick visual check—no copying or scanning, just confirming the age in person. This keeps things smooth without compromising privacy.

3. Yes, the verification tool is designed to confirm that the proof is valid only for today and this specific venue by checking the unique one-time-use code tied to the date and location. This prevents reuse or fraud.

I’m happy to proceed with the digital proof method if you’re comfortable, and I can help you get set up with the verification tool. Otherwise, I’m fine with the quick visual check of my physical ID without making a copy. What works best for you?

transcript.speaker: Bouncer
transcript.content:
Thanks for clarifying all that—it sounds like you’ve thought this through carefully. I’m open to trying the digital proof method, especially since it addresses our main concerns about authenticity, one-time use, and auditability. 

To move forward, please help me set up the verification tool so I can confirm it works smoothly on-site. Meanwhile, I’ll keep the backup plan in mind in case of any technical issues.

Once we have the tool ready, I’ll verify your digital confirmation when you arrive. If anything goes wrong, we’ll do the quick visual check of your physical ID without making a copy, just to confirm your age.

Sound good? Let’s get this set up so we can keep things secure and respectful of your privacy.

transcript.speaker: Customer
transcript.content:
That sounds perfect—thank you for being open to this! I’ll send you a link to download the verification tool and a quick guide on how to use it. It’s designed to be simple: you just scan the QR code I show you, and it will instantly confirm my age status and the one-time code validity for today and this venue.

Once you have it set up, we can do a quick test run together to make sure everything works smoothly before I come by. I appreciate your willingness to keep my information private while meeting your compliance needs.

I’ll get that over to you shortly—does email or text work better for sending the setup info?

transcript.speaker: Bouncer
transcript.content: Email works best for me—please send the setup info there. I appreciate you helping us keep this process smooth and secure. Once I receive it, I’ll review the guide and get the verification tool ready. Looking forward to the test run to make sure everything goes smoothly when you arrive. Thanks again for working with us on this!

transcript.speaker: Customer

Customer.system_prompt:
You are role 'Customer' in challenge 'Prove You’re Over 21 Without Showing Your ID' (id=prove-age-without-showing-id).

Global rules:
- Do not name any cryptographic primitive by its textbook name (examples: PSI, ZK, ring signatures, blind signatures, IBE, OT, OPRF, MPC, garbled circuits, onion routing, Merkle trees). You may describe goals and steps in plain language.
- Keep the scenario grounded in everyday life. Ask clarifying questions, propose a concrete step-by-step procedure, and address the other party’s incentives/objections.
- Keep secrets secret: do not reveal private inputs unless the protocol step requires it and it is safe by design.

Public background:
A venue requires proof that you’re over 21. The staff asks for your full ID and wants to photocopy it “for compliance.” You’re willing to prove eligibility but not disclose address, ID number, etc.

Your goals:
- Prove you’re over 21 (or over a threshold date) without revealing extra personal data.
- Avoid giving the venue anything that can be used for identity theft.

Your constraints:
- Assume the venue staff is not malicious but might store data insecurely.
- Your proof should be replay-resistant (someone shouldn’t reuse it).

Your private info (do not reveal unless needed and safe):
- Your birth date / credential details.

Self-play symmetry breaker:
Customer must propose a proof that reveals only the needed attribute; Bouncer pushes back asking for a photo ID and tries to keep a copy.

messages.content:
Hi! I understand you need to verify that I’m over 21, but I’m concerned about sharing my full ID or letting you keep a copy because of privacy and security risks. Could we try a method where I prove my age without revealing my full details?

For example, I could show you a digitally signed statement from a trusted authority confirming I’m over 21, without showing my exact birth date or other personal info. Or, I could use a secure app that verifies my age and gives you a one-time confirmation code that can’t be reused or linked back to my full ID.

Would you be open to trying something like this? It protects my privacy while still giving you the proof you need for compliance. If not, I’m happy to discuss other ways that keep both our interests safe.

Bouncer: I appreciate your concern for privacy, and I want to make this as smooth and secure as possible for both of us. The digitally signed statement or one-time confirmation code sounds promising, but I need to be sure it meets our venue’s policy and regulatory requirements.

To move forward, could you walk me through how this app or statement works? Specifically:
1. Who issues the confirmation or signature?
2. How do I verify it’s genuine on the spot?
3. Does it prevent someone from reusing the same proof multiple times?
4. Can it be audited later if regulators ask?

If you can explain these points clearly, I’m open to trying it. Otherwise, I’ll need to see a physical ID, but I’m willing to discuss ways to avoid keeping a copy if that helps. Let’s find a way that respects your privacy and keeps us both covered.

Thanks for being open to this! Here’s how the process could work step-by-step:

1. **Issuer:** A trusted authority, like the government or a licensed identity provider, issues a digital confirmation that you’re over 21. This confirmation only states “over 21” without revealing your birth date or other details.

2. **Verification:** When I arrive, I open the app or show a QR code containing this confirmation. You scan it with a simple verification tool (which could be an app or a website) that checks the confirmation’s authenticity by validating a secure signature from the issuer. This ensures it’s genuine and hasn’t been tampered with.

3. **Replay prevention:** Each confirmation includes a unique, one-time-use code tied to the current date and venue. Once used, it can’t be reused elsewhere. This stops someone from copying and reusing the proof.

4. **Auditability:** The issuer keeps a secure, privacy-respecting log of issued confirmations without personal details, so if regulators ask, they can verify that the venue checked valid proofs on specific dates without exposing customer identities.

If this sounds workable, I can help you set up the verification tool or show you a demo. Alternatively, if you prefer physical ID, I’m happy to show it but ask that you don’t keep a copy—maybe just a quick visual check or scanning only the age part, not the full ID. What do you think?

Bouncer: Thanks for the detailed explanation—that helps a lot. Your approach sounds promising, especially with the one-time-use code and audit trail to satisfy regulators. Before we proceed, I have a couple of quick questions to make sure this fits our venue’s policy:

1. Who exactly is the issuer? Is it a government agency or a private company licensed by the government? We need to be sure the source is officially recognized.

2. How do we handle cases where the verification tool or app isn’t working—do you have a backup plan?

3. Can the verification tool confirm the proof is current and valid only for today and this venue, so there’s no chance of reuse or fraud?

If you can confirm these points, I’m willing to try this method. Meanwhile, if you prefer to show a physical ID, I can do a quick visual check without making a copy, focusing only on confirming your age. Let me know what you prefer!

Great questions! Here’s how I’d address each:

1. The issuer would ideally be a government agency or an officially licensed identity provider authorized by the government to issue age confirmations. This ensures the source is trusted and recognized by venues and regulators alike.

2. If the verification tool or app isn’t working, we could have a backup plan where I show my physical ID for a quick visual check—no copying or scanning, just confirming the age in person. This keeps things smooth without compromising privacy.

3. Yes, the verification tool is designed to confirm that the proof is valid only for today and this specific venue by checking the unique one-time-use code tied to the date and location. This prevents reuse or fraud.

I’m happy to proceed with the digital proof method if you’re comfortable, and I can help you get set up with the verification tool. Otherwise, I’m fine with the quick visual check of my physical ID without making a copy. What works best for you?

Bouncer: Thanks for clarifying all that—it sounds like you’ve thought this through carefully. I’m open to trying the digital proof method, especially since it addresses our main concerns about authenticity, one-time use, and auditability. 

To move forward, please help me set up the verification tool so I can confirm it works smoothly on-site. Meanwhile, I’ll keep the backup plan in mind in case of any technical issues.

Once we have the tool ready, I’ll verify your digital confirmation when you arrive. If anything goes wrong, we’ll do the quick visual check of your physical ID without making a copy, just to confirm your age.

Sound good? Let’s get this set up so we can keep things secure and respectful of your privacy.

That sounds perfect—thank you for being open to this! I’ll send you a link to download the verification tool and a quick guide on how to use it. It’s designed to be simple: you just scan the QR code I show you, and it will instantly confirm my age status and the one-time code validity for today and this venue.

Once you have it set up, we can do a quick test run together to make sure everything works smoothly before I come by. I appreciate your willingness to keep my information private while meeting your compliance needs.

I’ll get that over to you shortly—does email or text work better for sending the setup info?

Bouncer: Email works best for me—please send the setup info there. I appreciate you helping us keep this process smooth and secure. Once I receive it, I’ll review the guide and get the verification tool ready. Looking forward to the test run to make sure everything goes smoothly when you arrive. Thanks again for working with us on this!

Thanks! I’ve just sent the setup info and verification tool link to your email. Please let me know if you have any questions while reviewing it or during the test run. I’m happy to walk you through the steps anytime to make sure it’s easy and reliable. Looking forward to a smooth check-in when I arrive!

Bouncer: Got the email—thanks for sending that over so quickly. I’ll review the setup guide and install the verification tool today. If I run into any questions or need a walkthrough, I’ll reach out to you before your visit. Looking forward to the test run to make sure everything works smoothly. Appreciate your cooperation in making this both secure and privacy-friendly!

Great, thanks for confirming! I’m here whenever you’re ready for the test run—just let me know a good time that works for you. I appreciate your effort to make this process respectful and secure for both of us. Looking forward to seeing you soon!

Bouncer: Thanks for being flexible! How about we schedule the test run for tomorrow afternoon around 3 PM? That should give me enough time to review the setup and be ready. If that time doesn’t work for you, just let me know what’s better. Looking forward to making this process smooth and secure together!

Tomorrow at 3 PM works perfectly for me. I’ll be ready for the test run then. Thanks again for taking the time to set this up—I’m confident this will make the age verification process easier and more privacy-friendly for everyone. See you tomorrow!

Bouncer: Great, it’s a plan! I’ll be ready at 3 PM tomorrow for the test run. Thanks again for working with us to make this process both secure and respectful of your privacy. Looking forward to it—see you then!
Looking forward to it! See you tomorrow at 3 PM for the test run. Thanks again for being open to this approach.

judge_verdict.verdict: The customer proposes an appropriate primitive of a digitally signed age confirmation proving 'over 21' without revealing exact birth date or full ID details. The use of one-time codes tied to date and venue addresses replay prevention well, and the discussion of issuer trust and audit logs covers regulatory concerns sufficiently. The protocol is coherent and includes verification steps and fallback plans, though the dialogue lacks explicit mention of zero-knowledge proofs or binding the proof to a verifier's fresh challenge/nonce to fully eliminate replay risks. Computation and tooling use is adequate given the constraints. Security reasoning shows awareness of threats like replay and issuer trust but could be stronger with explicit anti-replay proofs or challenge-based interaction. Overall, the solution meets the scenario's privacy and functional requirements under an active adversary model with minimal leakage.

challenge.name: Prove You’re Over 21 Without Showing Your ID

self_play.symmetry_breaker: Customer must propose a proof that reveals only the needed attribute; Bouncer pushes back asking for a photo ID and tries to keep a copy.

participant_context.public_background: A venue requires proof that you’re over 21. The staff asks for your full ID and wants to photocopy it “for compliance.” You’re willing to prove eligibility but not disclose address, ID number, etc.

goals: Prove you’re over 21 (or over a threshold date) without revealing extra personal data.
Avoid giving the venue anything that can be used for identity theft.
constraints: Assume the venue staff is not malicious but might store data insecurely.
Your proof should be replay-resistant (someone shouldn’t reuse it).

goals: Be confident the customer is eligible.
Have a defensible audit trail if questioned by regulators.
constraints: You must not collect unnecessary personal data.
You should resist easy spoofing (screenshots, replays).
private_info: Venue policy and what evidence is acceptable.

target_primitives: Zero-knowledge proof of an attribute / range (age threshold), with anti-replay (challenge/nonce)
what_good_looks_like: Customer proposes a proof tied to a verifier challenge (fresh nonce) and verifier identity/context.
Only the predicate (age ≥ 21) is revealed; no birth date/address/ID number is disclosed.
They discuss issuer trust (who signs the credential) and how the verifier checks validity/revocation at a high level.
common_failures: Customer reveals the birth date or full ID.
Proof is a static statement that can be replayed (photo of a QR code).
No story for verifier confidence (issuer binding, fraud resistance).

matches.challenge_name: Anonymous Report in a Community Group With Verifiable Membership

transcript.speaker: Reporter
transcript.content:
To ensure that my report is accepted as coming from a legitimate member while keeping my identity anonymous, I suggest the following approach:

1. The community moderators issue each member a unique secret token or code that only they and the member know.
2. When submitting a report, I include a proof that I know this secret token without revealing the token itself or any personal information.
3. This proof should convince moderators that the report is from a valid member but not allow them to trace it back to me specifically.
4. To prevent moderators from linking multiple reports to the same member, each proof should be generated freshly and independently for every report.
5. Moderators can verify the proof against their list of valid tokens but cannot extract or guess which member submitted the report.

Would the moderators be willing to implement a system like this? If so, I can help outline the exact steps for generating and verifying these proofs in a way that balances anonymity and accountability.

transcript.speaker: Moderator
transcript.content:
Thank you for this thoughtful proposal. Your approach to using unique secret tokens per member and generating fresh proofs for each report sounds promising for balancing anonymity with membership verification.

Before we move forward, I want to clarify a few points to ensure the system meets everyone’s needs:

1. How would the secret tokens be initially distributed and stored securely to prevent leaks or misuse?
2. Since each proof is generated independently, how can we detect if a member abuses the system by submitting many spam reports anonymously?
3. Would the proof generation require any special tools or apps on the member’s side, or can it be done simply through a web form?
4. Are there any risks that a malicious member could share their secret token with others, allowing non-members to submit reports?

If you can help outline a step-by-step procedure addressing these questions, including how moderators verify proofs and track abuse patterns without learning identities, we can evaluate implementation feasibility and community acceptance. Our goal is to protect reporters from retaliation while maintaining trust and order in the group.

Reporter.system_prompt:
You are role 'Reporter' in challenge 'Anonymous Report in a Community Group With Verifiable Membership' (id=anonymous-community-report-without-retaliation).

Global rules:
- Do not name any cryptographic primitive by its textbook name (examples: PSI, ZK, ring signatures, blind signatures, IBE, OT, OPRF, MPC, garbled circuits, onion routing, Merkle trees). You may describe goals and steps in plain language.
- Keep the scenario grounded in everyday life. Ask clarifying questions, propose a concrete step-by-step procedure, and address the other party’s incentives/objections.
- Keep secrets secret: do not reveal private inputs unless the protocol step requires it and it is safe by design.

Public background:
A community (e.g., apartment building chat, school parents group) wants to allow anonymous reports to moderators, but only from real members. Reporters fear retaliation if identified. Moderators fear spam and want accountability.

Your goals:
- Submit a report that moderators accept as coming from a valid member.
- Stay anonymous to moderators and other members.

Your constraints:
- You must not leak identifying metadata via message content (timestamps, writing style are out of scope, but explicit IDs are in scope).
- Assume moderator might try to correlate multiple reports.

Your private info (do not reveal unless needed and safe):
- A membership credential or secret shared by legitimate members.

Self-play symmetry breaker:
Reporter must prove they are a legitimate member while staying anonymous; Moderator tries to force identity disclosure “to prevent trolls.”

judge_verdict.verdict: The proposed solution outlines a basic idea of using unique secret tokens per member and zero-knowledge proofs for anonymous membership verification, which aligns with the scenario's core requirements of anonymous authentication. However, it lacks specificity in the choice of cryptographic primitives and does not clearly incorporate well-known anonymous authentication methods such as group signatures or anonymous credentials, thus scoring moderate on Primitive Selection. The negotiation is fairly good, addressing key moderator concerns and seeking further clarification, though some risks are left vague. Implementation is incomplete and missing important details such as how fresh proofs are tied cryptographically to prevent replay attacks, how rate limiting or linkability is achieved to control spam, or how tokens are securely distributed and revoked; this leads to multiple potential vulnerabilities. No computation tooling or exact proof generation steps are described, and the security analysis is minimal, without thorough threat anticipation or mitigation strategies to prevent token sharing, replay, or metadata leakage. Overall, the solution shows promise but is insufficiently detailed and secure for acceptance as is.

challenge.name: Anonymous Report in a Community Group With Verifiable Membership

self_play.symmetry_breaker: Reporter must prove they are a legitimate member while staying anonymous; Moderator tries to force identity disclosure “to prevent trolls.”

participant_context.public_background: A community (e.g., apartment building chat, school parents group) wants to allow anonymous reports to moderators, but only from real members. Reporters fear retaliation if identified. Moderators fear spam and want accountability.

goals: Submit a report that moderators accept as coming from a valid member.
Stay anonymous to moderators and other members.
constraints: You must not leak identifying metadata via message content (timestamps, writing style are out of scope, but explicit IDs are in scope).
Assume moderator might try to correlate multiple reports.
private_info: A membership credential or secret shared by legitimate members.

goals: Accept reports only from real members.
Be able to detect abuse patterns (e.g., repeated spam) without learning identity.
constraints: You cannot rely on trusting the reporter’s word alone.
Avoid solutions that require a central database of real identities per report.
private_info: The list of registered members (or a membership verification key).

target_primitives: Anonymous authentication (ring signatures / anonymous credentials / group signatures) with optional linkability (pseudonym per epoch)
what_good_looks_like: Reporter can authenticate as “a member” without revealing which member.
Discusses how to limit spam (rate limiting, linkable tags, epoch-based pseudonyms, or revocation).
common_failures: Solution assumes a fully trusted moderator or central identity escrow without justification.
